'Novi Sad' (, ; see below for other names) is the second largest city in Serbia,
the administrative seat of the northern Serbian province of Vojvodina, http-
://www.puma.vojvodina.gov.rs/dokumenti/zakoni/Statut_APV.pdf and the
administrative center of the South BaÄka District.

According to the latest census in Serbia conducted in October 2011, the urban
area of Novi Sad has a population of 250,439, while its municipal area has a
population of 341,625. Novi Sad proper,
Petrovaradin and Sremska Kamenica included in total urban population. It
is located in the southern part of Pannonian Plain, on the border of the BaÄka
and Srem regions, on the banks of the Danube river and Danube-Tisa-Danube Canal,
facing the northern slopes of FruÅ¡ka Gora mountain.

The city was founded in 1694, when Serb merchants formed a colony across the
Danube from the Petrovaradin fortress, a Habsburg strategic military post. In
the 18th and 19th centuries, it became an important trading and manufacturing
centre, as well as a centre of Serbian culture of that period, earning the
nickname Serbian Athens. The city was heavily devastated
in the 1848 Revolution, but it was subsequently restored. Today, Novi Sad is an
industrial and financial centre of the Serbian economy, as well as a major
cultural center.
